Hi All,

If possible could you review this PLDM transport layer wrapper design.

Thanks.

I don't have much of an influence above the transport layers, so I'm not going to set a score here, but some general comments:

Is this really worthwhile? there's not a lot of PLDM applications, so it seems that the introduction of a separate library is unnecessary. Does this avoid much duplicated infrastructure between applications?

Keep in mind that the transport APIs that you're abstracting are fairly vanilla (in the MCTP case, it's the standard socket syscalls), and don't involve much novel code.

Is it infeasible to interact directly with the transports in your application(s)?

I might be completely wrong about this though, in which case could you add a bit of rationale to the doc?

Hi Jeremey, Mainly our idea is to reuse the existing applications such as pldm sensor and pldm FW update.Since the current pldm service and apps has direct binding with the MCTP transport layer and our platform has PLDM support over NCSI, we wanted to introduce this transport wrapper layer.

The main idea behind this design is to keep the PLDM layer implementation as it is and abstract  the transport layer api's with the transport wrapper.

OK, so there are multiple applications, I see. In that case, the use of a library for this does make more sense.

In order to achieve this, you're also introducing a routing layer, of tids to their underlying transport addressing mechanism. I see you have a `discoverTIDs()` interface, but that doesn't seem sufficient. You may have:

- endpoints that appear after the application has called discoverTIDs(). Is the application supposed to continuously call this?

- endpoints that disappear; but no mechanism to inform the application that a tid is no longer valid

To solve these, you may need to process events outside of the PLDM send/receive flow...

@Jeremy, there are no multiple applications. With the current implementation/design, all the PLDM types will be implemented as part of the PLDM daemon.

@Naveen, Agree with the general intent that MCTP is not the only transport layer and PLDM should not be tied to MCTP and should abstract that to support other transport layers. But need to see more details on the transition from pldmd <-> mctp-demux-daemon to include pldmd <-> RBT communication. Also with Jeremy's MCTP kernel implementation, there will be a socket connection for every MCTP endpoint.

> @Jeremy, there are no multiple applications.

OK, why is this a library then?
I think this transport wrapper necessarily need not to be made as library, but it's apis should be used by the pldmd daemon for pldm requests.

Nit: Can reword this along the lines of - "PLDM being an application layer protocol can bind on other type of transports like NC-SI. To enable other types of transports that can carry PLDM traffic, a transport layer abstraction is required" (Basically, it is not the platforms that support other transport layers, but it the specifications that allow PLDM to bind on other transports)

+1

We need to draft this problem description to include the full scope of the problem you are trying to solve. I mean rather than just "PLDM transport wrapper on OpenBMC", something like "PLDM over RBT" or "PLDM Type 5 over RBT" etc. 

What are the use cases in your proposal?  Looking at the whitepaper( https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2015_2.0.0.pdf) "PLDM over NCSI based on RBT" is not a possibility. It is either "PLDM over RBT" or "NC-SI Control over RBT". Correct?

What is the difference between Req 1 & Req 2? I think not just the PLDM request API, but how does PLDM daemon as a responder handle different transport types should be discussed here.

I get the intent that instead of EID we should use terminus ID as the key for PLDM types to map to a socket.

Req 3 & Req 4 looks very similar. Is NC-SI control messages going to be be included in PLDM daemon? Would it be a socket based communication for NC-SI over RBT? More context is needed here.

1) What library is used for NC-SI over RBT?
2) How does PLDM daemon get to know that it is ready to do a discovery messages?
3) Does the PLDM daemon needs to communicate with multiple terminus id, if that is a scenario how does PLDM daemon get to know that.

The library should not be performing any EID discovery; that will have been performed by mctpd.

The library may access the results of MCTP control protocol enumeration over dbus though.

Right, I believe the intent here is to gather MCTP endpoints exposed over D-Bus. @Naveen, probably "triggers MCTP EID discovery" can be changed to "library gathers information about MCTP Endpoints exposed over D-Bus".
The discovered MCTP EID needs to support PLDM type. Not all MCTP EIDs would be interesting to pldmd

Using GetTID first to read TID of the device before we use SetTID(if TID is 0 in the response or if there is a TID collision) would be better.

DiscoverTIDs is an asynchronous process, readiness of the device cannot be guaranteed to be synchronous.

The idea here is to have a dedicated process which does the discovery of both MCTP and RBT based endpoints.so this is not need to be PLDM wrapper to call discoveryTID() routines, but the PLDM daemon can add support for discovery of RBT based endpoints as well.

This captures only "send-receive" flow - i.e. the pldmd wrapper handling instanceId matched responses. However, there are PLDM usecases where pldmd has to handle received payload and transmit a response (PLDM Firmware update flow). Can you please describe how this will be handled as well?
+1. Also, It will be easy to understand if it was a flow diagram.

Conceptually the proposal sounds good to me. I also suggest handling PLDM Type 0 inside the transport layer abstraction. The reason for doing so are as follows:
1) PLDM Type discovery can be done on a PLDM terminus and the transport abstraction (wrapper layer) can invoke the corresponding PLDM Type specific managers
2) In future, PLDM Type Version specific managers can be invoked as well
3) The transport abstraction (i.e. pldm wrapper) is required to handle "Set TID" command which is PLDM Type 0 command

Hi Patrick. initially we have proposed these pldm transport wrapper api's as separate shared library which will in turn route the underlying transport library api call based on tid.  with our latest pmci discussion regarding pldm transport abstraction, we have concluded that we will have the transport abstraction as a part of PLDM daemon source itself so these api's as a separate shared libraries is not needed but the respective transport(MCTP or NCSI over RBT) api can be handled directly from the pldm daemon itself.

This APIs were provided to enable PLDM requester flow[1] when it started with MCTP userspace[2] and for PLDM requesters to connect with mctp-demux-daemon. MCTP userspace repo is frozen and it doesn't accept any more patches and there is general agreement to switch to MCTP kernel space[3]. pldmd is yet to make the switch to use MCTP kernel space. These APIs are effectively going away once pldmd makes the switch to MCTP kernel.

It has to be beyond this too. The sequence needs to be:

1. pldmd registers a callback that handles new PLDM-capable devices appearing and disappearing from the system
2. pldmd enumerates the currently known PLDM-capable devices and assigns TIDs where necessary
3. pldmd continues to listen for the addition and remove of PLDM-capable devices, assigning TIDs where necessary

This doesn't make immediate sense to me. Discovery is a transport-specific problem and so attempting to implement it in the abstraction presented here seems wrong.

It's absolutely the case that the abstraction needs to interact with discovered devices _after_ they've been assigned a TID.
